oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Bell (February 15, 1797 - September 10, 1869) was a U.S. politician, attorney, and plantation owner. A wealthy slaveholder from Tennessee, Bell served in the United States Congress in both the House of Representatives and Senate. He began his career as a Democrat but eventually fell out with Andrew Jackson and became a Whig. In 1860, he was among a group of presidential candidates defeated by Abraham Lincoln in a bitterly divided election.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Satirical essay by anti-prohibitionists listing the "ten commandments" of prohibitionists, claiming all prohibitionists to be "rich," "hypocrites," usurpers," and "misleaders." The essay implies that the writers speak for the "poor" and adhere to the concepts of the Constitution and "free and independent people."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides
Broadsides; Prohibition; Prohibition -- United States; Temperance
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Prohibition movement was organized in the middle of the 19th century as part of a religious movement. As its popularity increased, several states banned consumption of alcohol. The 18th Amendment (passed 1917, ratified 1919) and the Volstead Act (passed 1920) both supplemented the movement, attempting to ban all alcohol in the United States. The 21st Amendment repealed the Prohibition laws in 1933.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Little Blind" Maud Cook (1875-1893) was a Manchester, Tennessee, native born to Nancy Casey and Samuel Cook. Blind from birth, she was regarded by many to be a musical prodigy, and she composed and performed her own music from an early age. Maud's sister Pearl was also born blind. Both young women remained small in stature throughout their lives, and both died before reaching the age of 20.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Kenneth Douglas McKellar was born in 1869. He was elected to the Senate in 1916 and was re-elected five times, serving from March 1917 to January 1953, finally losing his seat to Albert Gore in the 1952 election. He served as President Pro-Tempore in the Seventy-Ninth, Eighty-First, and Eighty-Second Congresses. He retired in 1953 and died in 1957.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The NAACP was founded in 1909, on the centennial of Lincoln's birth, by a coalition of prominent whites and African Americans. The organization fought major battles against Jim Crow laws, lynching, and segregation. Thurgood Marshall became Chief Counsel for the NAACP in 1940 and held the position until he was appointed to the Second Circuit of the U.S. Appeals Court in 1961. He was the first African American appointed to the U.S. Supreme Court in 1967, and he remained on the court until 1991.

Harry Belafonte is a successful Calypso artist and civil rights activist. Spottswood William Robinson III was a faculty member and later dean of Howard University School of Law. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Battle of Verdun took place between February and December 1916. A German army under Erich von Falkenhayn assaulted the French fortresses of Douamont and Verdun until driven back by the French defenders under Philippe Petain and Robert Neville. The battle resulted in a French halt to the German advance.

Broadsides; India; Burma; Lectures and lecturing
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wallace and Sons
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This broadside reflects a popular fascination with the exotic that was intensified by the British annexation of Burma in the 1880s. Tensions had been growing between Britain and Burma since the 1840s, and the issues of multiple sovereignty in the region had created further relationship difficulties. Britain's interests in the security of India and in Burma's raw materials and trade potential were factors that led to the establishment of British colonial authority in Burma in the 1880s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Summary of 1912 health report for Gallatin written by the City Health Officer, Dr. W. N. Lackey. The report statistically addresses mortality rates and births and provides a partial breakdown by sex, race, and age. It examines causes of death, with attention given to the decreasing threat from tuberculosis and the increasing threats from typhoid and improper water sources. It lists sanitary recommendations and emphasizes the need for a sewage system in Gallatin.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides; Announcements; Handbills; Fliers (printed matter)
Broadsides; Public health
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lackey, W. N.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Twentieth century public health records for Tennessee reflect an increasing emphasis on disease prevention and the increasing state responsibility for public health and education. Following major outbreaks of cholera and yellow fever across the state from 1832 through 1873, a State Board of Health was created for Tennessee in 1875, and many jurisdictions hired health officers. Localities became more involved in issues of public health and vital statistics, as this broadside illustrates.

Confederate widows' pensions were first issued in Tennessee in 1905.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Faced with the difficulties inherent in the unprecedented admission of a territory under the Northwest Ordinance of 1789 as well as the election-year struggle between the Federalists and the Jeffersonian Republicans, Tennessee sent a printed copy of its constitution and a report on census returns to Congress for approval on April 8, 1796. Tennessee became the sixteenth state admitted to the Union on June 1, 1796.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: The Rice Bureau
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: DeLong Rice was deeply inspired when he heard Bob Taylor speak in 1888. A business association ensued, leading to Rice's management of Taylor's lecture tours beginning in 1891. Taylor quickly became the highest-priced professional lecturer in the country. Rice organized his Rice Lyceum Bureau in 1900 and staged high-quality lecture and entertainment tours across the South. Such cultural events served as an educational resource for the audience.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Rag money" was paper currency made from linen and cotton fibers. A "shin-plaster" was printed small change. "Hard money" was coins made of a precious metal. This broadside was attempting to popularize these terms to be used as descriptions of political candidates.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: At the end of James K. Polk's administration, Polk, then in declining health, announced that he would not seek reelection. The Whigs, who had been fiercely critical of Polk's war policies, reversed course and named Mexican war hero Zachary Taylor as their presidential candidate, to run against former Democratic Senator Lewis Cass of Michigan. The Whigs were sharply denounced by their opponents as hypocrites.

Frank Clement's address at the 1956 Democratic National Convention ("How long oh Lord, how long..."), as well as assisting Robert Penn Warren with some of the speeches in his novel, "All the King's Men." He and his wife, Frances Neel Cheney (a grandniece of Sam Davis), lived in Smyrna, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Capers Memorial Christian Methodist Church began as the "African Mission" to the white McKendree Methodist Church. After preaching to slaves for many years, a commodious brick house was erected near Sulphur Springs for black church members. In 1851, Nashville's African American Methodists purchased a lot at Hine's and McCreary (11th Ave. North) and built a church.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Merl Rawls Eppse was born in 1893 in Greenville, Ohio. He attended Wilberforce University, Ohio State University and Drake University. He received his Master's Degree from Columbia University. From 1928 through 1960 he was professor and later chairman of the Department of History at Tennessee Agricultural and Industrial College (later Tennessee State University). He died in Los Angeles, California, December 27, 1967.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A gristmill or grist mill is a building where grain is ground into flour, or the grinding mechanism itself. In many countries these are referred to as corn mills or flour mills. Classical mill designs are usually water powered, though some are windmills, or powered by livestock. The millstones themselves turn at around 120 rpm. They are laid one on top of the other. The bottom stone, called the bed, is fixed to the floor, while the top stone, the runner, is mounted on a separate spindle.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Nashville Female Academy opened in 1816 and prospered through the eve of the Civil War, boasting enrollment of upwards of 500 students during its peak. In 1862, part of the structure was used as a hospital and occupied by Union troops until the end of the war. It reopened as Lanier Female Academy and finally closed in 1878.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Lousiville-Nashville Railroad, or L. & N. Railroad was a rail service that began operation in 1850, though the tracks were not laid from Louisville to Nashville until 1859. The rail line saw service in the Civil War and existed in various configurations before being consolidated into Seaboard System Railroads in 1982. Today, it is CSX. The R. J. Meigs referred to in this broadside is, in all probability, Return Jonathan Meigs, a member of the Committee which drafted the first Code of Tennessee (also known as the Meigs-Cooper Code).

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Calvin Brown, Confederate general and governor, was born in Giles County on January 6, 1827. After the Civil War, Brown resumed his Pulaski law practice. President of the 1870 Constitutional Convention, Brown was elected Tennessee's nineteenth governor after voters adopted the new constitution; he was reelected in 1872. Formerly a Whig, Brown joined the Democrats and was leader of the party's Bourbon faction. He died in 1889.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Patent medicine is a term given to various medical or pseudo-medical compounds sold under a variety of names and labels. The term has become particularly associated with the sale of drug compounds in the nineteenth century under cover of colorful names and even more colorful claims. The promotion of patent medicines was one of the first major successes of the advertising industry, and many advertising and sales techniques were pioneered by patent medicine promoters.

Minstrel shows lampooned African Americans as ignorant, lazy, buffoonish, superstitious, joyous, and musical. The heyday of the minstrel show was the period between 1840 and 1880.

By virtue of his position as Secretary of the Treasury, in August 1914 he also served as the first Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. He unsuccessfully ran for President in 1924.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Elizabeth Hutchison Jackson (ca. 1740 - November 2, 1781) was the mother of U. S. President Andrew Jackson. She was born in Carrickfergus, County Antrim, Ireland. She married Andrew Jackson, Sr. in Carrickfergus about 1765. After seeing her son, Andrew, through a near-fatal case of smallpox, she went to Charleston to nurse captured American soldiers languishing on British prisoner-of-war ships. She contracted cholera in Charleston and died when the future president was 14 years old.

The Party's stated goal is to achieve a free, prosperous, and peaceful society free of racism, sexism, homophobia, and exploitation, in which all people have the opportunity to develop to their fullest potential. The speaker at the advertised meeting, Israel Amter (1881-1954), was a Marxist politician and a founding member of the Communist Party USA.

As she indicates in the broadside, though raised locally, she spent time in New York and had twenty years of teaching experience by this date. She authored volumes of readers and spellers that would be published in Atlanta during the Civil War period. She and her contemporary female-teachers-turned-authors, however, were not responsible for any upper level Confederate textbooks.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: J.B. Wilson was born in Fayetteville in 1834. He learned the trade of cabinet-making as he worked in his father's shop from around 1850 until 1854. He then entered into a partnership with his father and brother as undertakers and furniture makers. Wilson enlisted in the 43rd Regiment C. S. A. when the war broke out. He picked up his trade after the war, and remained Fayetteville's leading furniture dealer and undertaker for decades.

Broadsides; Stagecoaches; Roads; Distances; Transportation; Mount Pleasant (Va.); Nashville (Tenn.); Lexington (Ky.); Cumberland Gap (Ky. and Va.); Winchester (Va.); Washington (D.C.); Richmond (Va.); Raleigh (N.C.); Taverns (Inns)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: With the Great Road (Wilderness Road) running through Abingdon and continuing on to Kingsport, Tennessee, Abingdon was a well-developed center of population for Southwest Virginia at the time of this bill. Stagecoach lines had been running out of Abingdon since the late 1700s. The first stages coming into Tennessee entered the eastern part of the state as extensions of Virginia routes like this one. Many stops were private residences, defense stations, or the homes of militia officers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Creek Indian tribes were disbanded and forced to come under Alabama law in 1832. When settlers began to infringe on Creek land, the Creek Indians revolted. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Phrenology was the study of skull features made popular in the early 19th Century. It is now largely considered to be a pseudo-science. The subject of this examination, "John A. Murril" is probably the infamous John A. Murrell, a colorful antebellum Tennessee outlaw.
